comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Kleanthis Vasardakis, Greek Consul General in San Francisco, was involved in a lawsuit in 1916

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: @LOC, FYI, this is listed and indexed in the LOC PPOC as "Cleanthe Vasardak's". As to the variant in spelling of "Cleanthe" vs. "Kleanthis" in the (Special to The New York Times) article referenced by trialsanderrors, The New York Times reported on May 12, 1919, on a meeting of the National Association of the Dodecanesians in New York City, in which they referred to "Dr. C. Vasardakis, formerly Greek Consul General at San Francisco". -- which doesn't truly clean (or klean) anything up ... as the Official Congressional Directory, Volume 64, Issue 2, Part 1, lists the Consul General as "Kleanthis Vasardakis". Then, there's the matter of his (likely) wife... "Mme. Cleanthe Vasardakis"   by Bain/LOC

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Hmm, the name comes from Κλεάνθης, Kleanthēs, in the English transliteration Cleanthes but in the French Cléanthe: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleanthes

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: @ trialsanderrors, Well done on the different transliterations of Κλεάνθης. I 'cheated' a bit and called a native Greek citizen who told me there is not a letter "C" in Greek, and the name would end in "this", as in Kleanthis. If that information is accurate, then this article from the March 19, 1916, New York Times would have the correct spelling of "Kleanthis Vasardakis", as would this November 25, 1920, New York Tribune article -- and is the spelling you first referenced in your comment on this photograph!
